properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Yarra Ranges National Park and Surrounds
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Yarra Ranges National Park and Surrounds
  • There is a bushfire at Yarra Ranges National Park, north of Old Woods Point Road, that is not yet under control.
  • The Upper Yarra Recreational Reserve Campground has been closed.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/02/2025 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Lillimur. 
  • The fire in the Western Section of the Little Desert National Park has been contained.
  • Firefighters will continue to patrol this fire and respond to hot spots.
  • Smoke from within the fire area may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 09/02/2025 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: areas surrounding Little Desert National Park
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for areas surrounding Little Desert National Park
  • This Advice replaces the 3 Advice messages issued at 12.43 pm, 8 February.
  • The bushfire in the Little Desert National Park is now contained. 
  • Some areas of active fire may remain within containment lines
  • Fire crews will remain in the area treating hazardous trees, monitor hot spots and consolidate containment lines .
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Major roads in the area are now open.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • The Little Desert National Park is closed to visitors.
  • Check the Parks Victoria website for current information about where you can visit.
Smoke
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/02/2025 03:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: areas around Snowy Bluff, Mt Darling including Wonnangatta Valley
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for areas around Snowy Bluff, Mt Darling including Wonnangatta Valley.

  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 11:12am Friday 7 February 2025.
  • There is a small bushfire at Mt Darling - Snowy Bluff that is not yet under control.
  • Due to the fire in the adjacent Snowy Bluff - Mt Darling Wilderness, the McMillans Walking Trail between Moroka Junction Track and Moroka River Track is closed. 
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads.
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
  • Heavy machinery is operating in the area constructing fallback containment breaks. 
  • Roads remain open however be aware that heavy machinery is currently operating on Howitt Road, Moroka Road, Zeka Spur Track, Moroka Junction Track, Doolans Plain Track and Moroka River Track.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 09/02/2025 05:50 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: areas surrounding the Grampians National Park affected by the Wallaby Rocks (Victoria Range) fires
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for areas surrounding the Grampians National Park affected by the Wallaby Rocks (Victoria Range) fires .
  • This advice message replaces the Advice messages issued at 4.06 pm and 4.07 pm February 7 and 10.27 am February 8.  
  • The bushfire in the Grampians National Park - Wallaby Rocks (Victoria Range) is now contained. 
  • Some areas of active fire may remain within containment lines. 
  • Fire crews will remain in the area treating hazardous trees, monitor hot spots and consolidate containment lines. 
  • Smoke will be visible in the area. 
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway is now open with reduced speed limits. 
  • Obey all speed restrictions and road closure signs.
  • Police will be patrolling the area.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park
  • The Grampians Tourist road from Dunkeld to Halls gap is open. 
  • Halls Gap township is open. 
  • While most of the Grampians National Park is closed, some popular areas and visitor sites are open to the public such as the Wonderland Loop Walk which includes The Pinnacle, Venus Baths and Grand Canyon. Chataqua Peak, Clematis Falls, Bullaces Glen and Boronia Peak are also open. 
  • Mt Abrupt, Mt Sturgeon and Piccaninny walking tracks are closed.
  • Check the Parks Victoria website for current information about where you can visit.
Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/02/2025 04:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: areas east of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for areas east of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire. 
  • The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill, known as the Yarram Gap Road fire, is under control. 
  • This Community Information replaces the Advice message issued at 12.47pm 7 February.
  • Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines.
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
  • There is another fire in the western part of the Grampians known as the Wallaby Rocks Fire where fire crews continue to strengthen containment lines. Smoke may be visible from nearby communities. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Drive with caution. Obey road closure signs.  
  • Visitors are reminded to be cautious of ongoing risks and changes to the environment which may include fallen or damaged trees, smoke and injured wildlife.
  • If you see impacted wildlife - call 1300 356 682. 

Impacts in the Area:
  • Drivers may encounter fire crews and heavy machinery on roads and tracks. Please take care and drive safely. 
  • Many roads within the fire affected area remain closed. Check the VicTaffic website or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Grampians National Park (Gariwerd)
  • The Grampians Tourist road from Dunkeld to Halls gap is open. 
  • Halls Gap township is open. 
  • While most of the Grampians National Park is closed, some popular areas and visitor sites are open to the public such as the Wonderland Loop Walk which includes The Pinnacle, Venus Baths and Grand Canyon. Chataqua Peak, Clematis Falls, Bullaces Glen and Boronia Peak are also open. 
  • Mt Abrupt, Mt Sturgeon and Piccaninny walking tracks are closed.
  • Check the Parks Victoria website for current information about where you can visit. 

Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000). 


This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 13/02/2025 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Falls Creek, Bogong, Mitta Mitta, Mount Beauty, Nelse
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Bogong, Falls Creek, Mitta Mitta, Mount Beauty, Nelse. 

  • This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued at 9.56pm on Friday 7th February.
  • Due to recent thunderstorm activity, there are currently four bushfires burning around the Falls Creek, Bogong and Alpine National Park areas.
These fires are located: 
  • 1.5km northwest of Falls Creek.
  • 5km north of Falls Creek.
  • 9km northeast of Falls Creek.
  • 19km southeast of Mount Beauty.
  • Firefighters are currently responding to this fire.
  • You will see firefighting vehicles and equipment on Bogong High Plains Road.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 09/02/2025 11:10 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
